title: Employment Code (Domestic Workers Minimum Wages and Conditions of Employment) Order, 2023
content:
24th November, 2023 Statutory Instruments 299
GOVERNMENT OF ZAMBIA
Statutory Instrument No. 49 of 2023
The Employment Code Act, 2019
(Act No. 3 of 2019)
The Employment Code (Domestic Workers Minimum
Wages and Conditions of Employment) Order, 2023
In exercise of the powers contained in section 106 of the
Employment Code Act, 2019, the following Order is made:
1. (1) This Order may be cited as the Employment Code Title and
(Domestic Workers Minimum Wages and Conditions of Commence­
ment
Employment) Order, 2023.
(2) This Order shall come into operation on 1 st January, 2024.
2. (1) This Order shall apply to a domestic worker. Application
(2) This Order shall not apply to an employee —
(a) in an occupation where wages and conditions of
employment are regulated through the process of
collective bargaining in accordance with the Industrial Cap. 269
and Labour Relations Act;
(b) in a sector where the Minister has prescribed the minimum
wage; and
(c) who performs domestic work on a piece work basis.
(3) The provisions of this Order shall not be used as the basis
for any negotiations in a contract of employment for an employee
that is exempt under subparagraph (2).
3. In this Order, unless the context otherwise requires— Interpretation
“child” has the meaning assigned to the word in the
Constitution; Cap.l
“dependant” means a person who is eighteen years old or
below, and resides in the home of a domestic worker but
does not include the domestic worker’s child;

“domestic work” means work performed in or for a household;
“domestic worker” means a person engaged in domestic work
within an employment relationship; and
“employer” means a person who has entered into a contract
of employment with a domestic worker.
Wages 4. (1) The minimum wage for a domestic worker, excluding
an amount paid in lieu of rations, shall not be less than five Kwacha
and twenty nine ngwee (K5.29) per hour or one thousand, one
hundred Kwacha (KI, 100.00) per month.
(2) A domestic worker shall, where the domestic worker was
in receipt of a wage in excess of the minimum wage prior to the
commencement of this Order, retain the wage on the
commencement of this Order.
(3) A domestic worker shall be paid wages at regular intervals
as follows—
(a) in the case of a monthly paid domestic worker, on the last
day of each month; and
(b) in the case of a domestic worker who is employed to
perform a task, on completion of the task.
Separation 5. (1) A domestic worker shall, where a domestic worker’s
package contract of employment is terminated, be entitled to separation
benefits of not less than one month’s basic pay for every two
completed years of service and any other dues.
(2) Despite subparagraph (1), a domestic worker shall not be
entitled to both separation benefits and gratuity.
Transport 6. A domestic worker who resides beyond a three kilometre
allowance radius from the place of work shall be paid a monthly allowance of
two hundred Kwacha (K200.00) for transport expenses unless the
employer provides transport for that domestic worker.
Personal 7. A domestic worker who does any work likely to be injurious
protective
to the domestic worker shall be provided with personal protective
equipment
equipment.
Revocation 8. The Minimum Wages and Conditions of Employment
of Statutory
(Domestic Workers) Order, 2011, is revoked.
